Delta strain of Covid-19 identified in Melbourne cases linked to traveller who returned from Sri Lanka and entered hotel quarantine on 8 May

  • Victoria‚Äôs new Covid lockdown restrictions explained
  • List of Victoria Covid public exposure sites; NSW hotspots
trailText: Delta strain of Covid-19 identified in Melbourne cases linked to traveller who returned from Sri Lanka and entered hotel quarantine on 8 May
body:
Victorians are ‚Äúon track‚Äù to enjoy eased Covid restrictions from Friday, the acting premier, James Merlino, has said, with the two new cases announced in the state on Tuesday linked to existing cases.

Health authorities also revealed that genomic sequencing has linked the Delta strain of Covid-19 that spread in West Melbourne to a traveller who returned from Sri Lanka and entered hotel quarantine on 8 May.

While he tested positive in hotel quarantine and was moved to a health hotel on 9 May before finishing quarantine on 23 May, authorities are puzzled as to how the man in his 40s transmitted the virus to other cases in the West Melbourne cluster.

The man lives in the Glen Eira LGA, in Melbourne‚Äôs southeast, and the other 23 passengers on his flight, aircrew, Skybus crew, and hundreds of staff from both hotels linked to the man have tested negative.

Related: Australia news live: Victoria finds source of Delta Covid outbreak; Biloela child reportedly diagnosed with pneumonia

‚ÄúI can confirm that so far there is no reported or obvious breach of infection prevention control protocols or anything else that would indicate a transmission has happened inside the hotel,‚Äù Danny Pearson, acting police and emergency services minister, said.

Allen Cheng, Victoria‚Äôs deputy chief health officer, said of four theories authorities are exploring about how Covid spread from the man, the ‚Äúmost likely‚Äù was that he transmitted the virus to another hotel guest or to a staff member when being transferred to the Holiday Inn health hotel.

Of the two new cases announced on Tuesday, one is a child linked to the West Melbourne Delta variant cluster, and the other is a household contact of a worker linked to the Kappa variant outbreak at the Arcare Maidstone aged care facility.

Merlino said both of the new cases have had limited community exposure, as they were primary contacts of known cases.

Related: Australians have been forgiving of the government‚Äôs Covid response, but we may have reached our limit | Peter Lewis

While flagging an easing of restrictions to take effect from Friday, Merlino said public health advice meant that travel between metropolitan Melbourne and regional Victoria would continue to be restricted over the long weekend.

‚ÄúThat will extend beyond any announcements that we will make later in the week. There are very good reasons for that. We absolutely want to run this into ground and ensure that there‚Äôs no risk of this spreading out into regional Victoria. We wanted to be up-front and honest with people at the earliest opportunity.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to foreshadow what we are going to announce. We are still...working through all the elements. It is a day-by-day, hour by hour analysis about how we are tracking ‚Ä¶ We remain on track to provide that easing of restrictions to all Victorians,‚Äù Merlino said.

There are now 85 local cases of Covid-19 in Victoria.

Asked if the genomic discovery of the Delta variant‚Äôs origins constituted a failure of hotel quarantine, Merlino reiterated the shortcomings of hotel design and how his state has been pursuing a purpose-built quarantine facility.

Related: Where did Australia‚Äôs first cases of the Covid Delta variant come from and how infectious is it?

‚ÄúWe are making it as risk-free as humanely possible but it has never ever been a zero-risk environment. That is not the nature of hotels. Hotels are built for tourists. They‚Äôre not built to tackle infectious disease,‚Äù Merlino said.

He also said that any purpose-built quarantine facility would act alongside hotel quarantine, and could be used to support higher risk returned travellers.

Merlino was also scathing of the Victorian opposition‚Äôs demand for premier Daniel Andrews to release details of his back injury, saying the state Liberal party ‚Äúshould be ashamed of themselves‚Äù.

Elsewhere on Tuesday, Western Australia‚Äôs premier Mark McGowan announced residents aged 30 to 49 will be able to receive the Pfizer Covid vaccine from Thursday, while South Australia expanded its vaccine eligibility to those aged 40-49.

headline: England must choose between pace and technique in their forward planning
standfirst: The speed of Sterling and Rashford had seemed the default option in support of Kane, but can Southgate afford to leave the skills of Foden and Grealish on the substitutes‚Äô bench?
trailText: The speed of Sterling and Rashford had seemed the default option in support of Kane, but can Southgate afford to leave the skills of Foden and Grealish on the substitutes‚Äô bench?
body:
Welcome to the month of living dangerously. At the end of the strangest, most fractured build-up to any modern tournament England‚Äôs footballers have at least avoided one familiar pitfall.

Too often this has been a tale of boredom and stale systems, of hotel-emptiness and simply waiting for things to start.

Sven-G√∂ran Eriksson passed those endless tournament training sessions wandering around the practice pitch chatting with David Beckham. Right then. We‚Äôre playing 4-4-2. The team is the team. Now, David. Another turn?

Related: Harry Kane feels England in ‚Äòbetter place‚Äô than at 2018 World Cup

At one point during the 2010 World Cup Jermain Defoe and Wayne Rooney were reduced to spending an evening in Rooney‚Äôs room watching the entire DVD recording of his wedding.

Fast-forward to the week-long prep for Euro 2020 and one thing seems clear. It won‚Äôt be boring. Six days away from their opening fixture England‚Äôs players, supporters and opponents still have no real idea of their starting team or indeed starting formation.

The manager will have a clearer view. But the alarming truth is that the chief question remains essentially unanswered. And right now England are perilously close to the strangest of outcomes, whereby their two most talented creative players, their two best keepers of the ball, Phil Foden and Jack Grealish, are unable to find their way into the system.

Southgate maintains that he knows his best team, with one exception. But the attacking plan, whatever it is, will still have to be pulled out of the air without any sustained practice run.

The base formula still goes like this. And yes, it is a complex, ill-formatted equation, for complex, ill-formatted times. Right now England‚Äôs best attack = (Harry Kane) + (x + y), but only where Kane + (x + y) features the quality ‚Äúpace‚Äù; and where if x = Foden then y cannot = Grealish.

This changes when Kane + (x+y) is fed into a 4-3-3 formation, which opens up a whole new set of variables. So far Southgate seems unwilling to go with the 4-3-3 against better teams in the absence of Harry Maguire. This may change for the Croatia game. It probably should.

So where are we with this? Who are the starters? There has until recently been an assumption the default option, x and y, are Raheem Sterling and Marcus Rashford as the wide players. Both have a ‚Äúman in possession‚Äù feel. Southgate and Kane both respond well to speed in attack.

Two things present themselves at this point. First, Southgate wants to play Mason Mount but won‚Äôt trust him as part of a two-man pivot, so Mount has probably now edged into that front three. Secondly Foden, Grealish and indeed Mount just seem to offer more, to be demonstrably better, more technical attacking footballers.

And look more closely and Southgate has pretty much moved on from this front three. The last time Kane, Rashford and Sterling started together was in the 6-0 win in Bulgaria two years ago, and before then on a run of games when England were settled on a 4-3-3.

More recently Southgate has tended to favour Kane, one of Sterling/Rashford, plus one other. In this equation Sterling and Rashford are now going for one spot. And Sterling will win that battle. He may have had a poor season ‚Äì and when Sterling does bad he really does bad, a player for whom the ball is suddenly square. But Sterling also has 12 England goals and 10 assists since the World Cup.

Plus there is the Kane effect. Kane has scored in 15 games for England since 2017, only one of those when Sterling has not started. Sterling is his most regular assister. That chemistry has been a defining element in this team. Southgate will surely reach for it now.

Right now the final member of that front three is surely Mount, who is a wonderful footballer, who can score, create, press, cover, take set pieces.

A front five of Declan Rice, Jordan Henderson/Kalvin Phillips, Sterling, Mount and Kane is a good, high-end, hard-working front five. And yet it retains that familiar absence of ball-hogging technical mastery, of the ability to change the tempo of the game, to hold the ball in any kind of space, all of which are recurrent England tournament failings.

This England crop does have these qualities. In Foden it has an English midfield talent unlike any other in recent memory, and in Grealish an utterly fearless manipulator of the ball. And yet through caution, by covering for other possibilities, we have arrived at a scenario where neither can actually get in the XI.

Two things could yet derail this possibility. Southgate could simply get over his terror of a Maguire-less back four. This would allow Mount to be included in the central three, and free up a space for Foden or Grealish (narrator‚Äôs voice: ‚ÄúFoden‚Äù) up front. This is the most attractive outcome and one that may yet come to pass given some hints offered after the Romania game.

The other thing is events. Stuff happens. Multiple substitutes are allowed at these Euros. Other shapes and combinations will present themselves. Games will become broken, chemistry will spark. There is a strong possibility England may end up with a very different starting XI by the end.

Related: How we made Three Lions: David Baddiel and Ian Broudie on England‚Äôs Euro 96 anthem

And why not evolve this team on the hoof? There is a theory that Southgate became fixated on the wrong England victory, the wrong England template, that he was overly charmed by the second-half solidity against Belgium in October 2020, after which Southgate raved at length about defensive detail and ‚Äúcompact covering positions‚Äù.

England also needed an iffy penalty and a deflected shot against Belgium. And they have won other games well. The visceral, counterattacking 3-2 against Spain. Or how about the one that got away, the 4-0 against Iceland in November 2020, in which Southgate fielded a back three with Rice and Mount as the pivot, Bukayo Saka at wing-back and Kane, Grealish and Foden as the front three?

Iceland were poor opponents. But that England XI has never been seen since. Would they really be in a worse position if it were this victory Southgate had been taken with, if that more progressive team, closer to the Premier League champions in its balance, able to defend by keeping the ball, had been given a few more run-outs? Would anyone be looking forward to these Euros-of-desperation any less?

The real fear at this point is a slow start with Grealish and Foden, darlings of the crowd, unable to find a spot: managing the sympathies of a changeable, angsty English public will also be a factor at this tournament.

headline: Global carbon dioxide levels continued to rise despite pandemic
standfirst: Emissions rose to 419 parts per million in May, the highest such measurement in the 63 years that the data has been recorded
trailText: Emissions rose to 419 parts per million in May, the highest such measurement in the 63 years that the data has been recorded
body:
The data is in: carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere hit 419 parts per million in May. The levels have now reached the dangerous milestone of being 50% higher than when the industrial age began ‚Äì and the average rate of increase is faster than ever.

The figure is the highest measurement of the crucial greenhouse gas in the 63 years that data has been recorded at the Mauna Loa Atmospheric Baseline Observatory in Hawaii ‚Äì despite slowdowns in air travel and industry during a global pandemic in the past year.

The 10-year average rate of increase also set a record, now up to 2.4 parts per million per year.

According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the reason is complex. Global emissions fell by 6.4% in 2020, but given the seasonal and natural variability, modest decreases wouldn‚Äôt make a big impact on the global tally of carbon emissions. And even as emissions dropped, wildfires burning through trees released carbon dioxide ‚Äì maybe even at a similar rate as the modest lowering of emissions from the pandemic‚Äôs slowing impact on the global economy.

I wonder how many people reading this can say with certainty that a specific summer ‚Äúwas the best summer of my life‚Äù. Maybe you went to loads of festivals when you were young and carefree, and the weather was uncharacteristically perfect for camping (2018 too hot, 2012 too wet, 1976 too hot and the toilet situation too unpredictable). Maybe you‚Äôre an enormous fan of the Romanian tennis player Simona Halep, and her Wimbledon win in 2019 sustained you throughout the rest of that July and August. For thousands of Welsh football fans, the question is an easy one.

In 2016 ‚Äúthis is the best summer of my life‚Äù was something we‚Äôd mutter to ourselves, wild-eyed with gleeful disbelief, as we bumped into each other in Bordeaux, Lille, Paris and Toulouse. It was better than we could ever have imagined. Complete strangers making friends, in a way that comes naturally when you walk into a bar and see another group of people holding a Welsh flag with the name of an impossibly small village written on it in felt tip. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôll be people from all over the planet watching tonight‚Äôs game mate, so with any luck, they‚Äôll get to see the name ‚Ä¶ Ffostrasol.‚Äù

Related: ‚ÄòIt was really like a group of mates on a lads‚Äô holiday‚Äô: Wales at Euro 2016

It‚Äôs five years ago now, but my mind routinely drifts back to France. Wales hadn‚Äôt qualified for anything since 1958 (we actually got to the quarter-finals of the 1976 European Championship, but technically the final tournament didn‚Äôt begin until the semi-finals in those days so, much to Terry Yorath and John Toshack‚Äôs chagrin, it doesn‚Äôt officially count. Much to my chagrin, it was four years before I was born).

Eight tournaments between 1960 and 2014 that we‚Äôd been within a game of qualifying for, a heartbreaking list of near-misses that the battle-hardened true believers could reel off in that way musicians can reel off the ways they were let down by their record label. I wouldn‚Äôt say getting to the semi-finals of Euro 2016 made up for those failures, as I‚Äôd have loved to see Ian Rush at Mexico ‚Äô86, and Ryan Giggs at USA ‚Äô94, but it did mean that once we were there we made the most of it. The release of almost 60 years‚Äô worth of frustration. We drank and danced in that way anyone would, if you were finally allowed into a party you‚Äôd dreamed of attending since you were a kid.

We deleted photos of our children from our phones so we could take photos of Hal Robson-Kanu warming up. Some people quit their jobs to be there, some nutters drove from Aberystwyth to Toulouse in a minibus, some people are still paying off their credit cards. No one wanted to miss a second. When we remembered the unlikely ways we‚Äôd managed to mess up qualifying in the past it was agreed this could be a once-in-a-lifetime thing.

A common refrain as 24,000 of us walked to the ground in Bordeaux for the first game against Slovakia was: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd just like to see us score a goal. Just one. I‚Äôll be happy after we‚Äôve sung the anthem, but I‚Äôd just love to see a goal.‚Äù When you are from a country big enough to produce a John Charles but small enough to make him play alongside someone from the Third Division (South), being there is what counts. You hear platitudes about certain players being ‚Äúfans‚Äô representatives on the pitch‚Äù, but I could relate to every one of our team. And when Chris Gunter did his famous ‚Äúchin up‚Äù sign to the Wales end after we‚Äôd lost the second group game to England in Lens, I felt that they related to us too. In the era of the millionaire footballer, it was like 11 fans had been plucked from the stands and somehow hammered Russia 3-0. We loved them, and, unburdened from expectation, they played as if they didn‚Äôt have a care in the world.

Catherine Zeta Jones ‚Ä¶? OK, if you look at England, Liverpool, yes, the Beatles ‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs on the left.‚Äù

I thought we did our part as fans, as well. headline: Daniel Levy the common denominator in Tottenham‚Äôs endless managerial farce
standfirst: The chairman operates a small circle of loyal nodding dogs and his unchecked power is draining away the hope at Spurs
trailText: The chairman operates a small circle of loyal nodding dogs and his unchecked power is draining away the hope at Spurs
body:
Like the proverbial tree falling in the forest, or the sound of no hands clapping, the prospect of Antonio Conte not joining Tottenham Hotspur has a certain paradoxical quality to it. Conte joining Tottenham: on some level, I suspect we all knew how this would pan out. The initial fire-streak of success; a brief title challenge; the inevitable implosion and acrimonious divorce, leaving only bittersweet memories and a squad packed with unshiftable 29-year-old wing-backs.

But Conte not joining: somehow this feels meaningful and epic in itself, a mini-tale of clashing egos and competing ambitions and insecurity and longing all packed into a week-long heavily briefed news cycle. And for all the disputed details of their courtship ‚Äì are we really to believe Tottenham pulled the plug on one of the world‚Äôs best coaches out of concern for the development of Oliver Skipp? ‚Äì there is a sense that even this apparent non-event has subtly wrinkled the fabric of the universe.

Related: Tottenham call off move for Antonio Conte after talks with coach break down

Conte, of course, will be fine. Though he may be short of options right now, he has successfully positioned himself as the gold-embossed, club-class option for the next ailing superclub with a trophy drought and a Nasa-sized transfer budget. The sabre-rattling, the lavish demands, the fixation on instant success: for his part the last couple of weeks have just been a brand-burnishing exercise, a reminder to oligarchs the world over that the Conte luxury marque is still in business.

The more interesting question, really, is where this leaves Tottenham. Almost two months after Jos√© Mourinho was sacked Daniel Levy is still searching for his replacement. The chairman‚Äôs preferred option, Julian Nagelsmann, went to Bayern Munich. Hansi Flick took the German national job. Brendan Rodgers seems quite happy at Leicester for now. An eye-catching flirtation with Mauricio Pochettino appears to have come to nothing. In the midst of which, and seemingly at random, a new director of football (Fabio Paratici) has been hired from Juventus.

Now Conte has also spurned their advances, any prospective new manager will know that he or she is ‚Äì at best ‚Äì fifth choice. And, more tellingly, that Levy‚Äôs stated commitment to ‚Äúfree-flowing, attacking football‚Äù and youth development extends only as far as the next superstar coach who makes eyes at him. In many ways this is the tension that has defined the modern Tottenham: a club eternally caught between long-term processes and short-term obsessions, a team that for all its moderate success on the pitch still has no real idea what it wants to be.

Levy is the common denominator here, the common signature at the bottom of two decades of eclectic, reflex managerial hires. Mourinho‚Äôs confrontational pragmatism was a reaction to the inclusive idealism of Pochettino, which was a reaction to the British bluntness of Tim Sherwood, which was a reaction to the gnomic intellectualism of Andr√© Villas-Boas, which was a reaction to the homespun wisdom of Harry Redknapp, which was a reaction to the continental technocracy of Juande Ramos, and so on. Even the current farce has its own precedent from 2003-04, when the promised ‚Äúthorough search‚Äù for Glenn Hoddle‚Äôs replacement ‚Äì with names like Vicente del Bosque, Klaus Toppm√∂ller and Martin O‚ÄôNeill all mooted ‚Äì ended in the caretaker manager David Pleat remaining in charge for nine months.

Clearly Levy has a fine instinct for commerce. And yet in any normal business there would be some sort of reckoning for the serial errors that have occurred on his watch: a hierarchy to answer to, consequences to confront. Even the much-maligned Ed Woodward at Manchester United has to face the shareholders every few months. Levy, by contrast, operates a small circle of loyal nodding dogs, with an absentee owner in Joe Lewis who may as well be propped up by pillows and sticks. With fans locked out and largely ignored in any case, Levy basically has untrammelled power to keep messing up and getting away with it. How curious that the ninth richest club in the world has somehow ended in a position where the major footballing decisions are being taken by a guy who ‚Äì with the greatest of respect ‚Äì does not really seem to know that much about football. This much is evident from the club‚Äôs Amazon documentary, in which the normally reclusive Levy is clearly at pains to present himself as some superior footballing intellect, only to come across as the bloke who sits next to you on a plane and tells you about how he won the Champions League with Bolton on Football Manager.

And so the search goes on: led by Levy, assisted by Paratici or perhaps by Steve Hitchen, the head of recruitment who has just been demoted by Paratici‚Äôs arrival. Meanwhile Harry Kane drifts towards the exit, Son Heung-min will turn 29 without a club trophy to his name, √ârik Lamela still collects a weekly wage and the under-23s lost 6-1 to Manchester City last month.

Is there a theme to any of this? Maybe caprice and human error: the inevitable product of tying your club‚Äôs fate to one man‚Äôs vanity. Together with the doomed European Super League, it is hard not to see Tottenham‚Äôs pursuit of Conte as their last shot at leveraging whatever remained of their Big Club status.

The pandemic has bitten hard; the stadium still needs paying for. And whether it is Erik ten Hag or Graham Potter or Roberto Mart√≠nez at the helm, Tottenham‚Äôs world feels just a little smaller this week, a little darker, a little less hopeful. A bright new dawn that turned out to be another illusion: insofar as the modern Tottenham does have an identity, this might just be it.

headline: Afghan interpreters say Australian visa offer is not enough to get them to safety
standfirst: Government has granted 90 visas to Afghans who worked with Australian forces, but they say they need military flights to flee revenge of the Taliban
trailText: Government has granted 90 visas to Afghans who worked with Australian forces, but they say they need military flights to flee revenge of the Taliban
body:
The federal government says it has granted an extra 90 visas since the beginning of May to Afghan nationals who have worked alongside Australian forces, but interpreters still in the country warned there were still many obstacles to them escaping the revenge of the Taliban.

Guardian Australia understands officials have offered to help the Afghans get on commercial flights to Australia in the near future, but one interpreter still in Afghanistan said he knew of about 15 colleagues who had been approved for resettlement but were unable to fly in the near future because the Covid pandemic meant no flights were available.

Speaking from Kabul on Tuesday, he said that without access to military flights, their situation would not change.

‚ÄúIf they can‚Äôt relocate us, what is the point of having a visa?‚Äù the man said. He was among 41 interpreters who wrote to the government twice earlier this year pleading for urgent help.

Last month Australia suddenly closed its Kabul embassy, saying it could not guarantee the security of staff in the light of the impending withdrawal of Australian troops by 11 September.

On Tuesday another interpreter said his family was awaiting passports, but without access to the embassy and its staff he had no certainty of being able to leave.
